conclusion: The light source is currently positioned directly above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The distance between the light source and the objects is such that the shadows are relatively large compared to their actual sizes.
If the light source moves forward (towards the viewer), the light rays will come from a more oblique angle relative to the ground plane.
As the light source moves forward, the angle between the light rays and the ground increases, causing the shadows to stretch out farther from the objects.
Shadow A is cast by the object near the top left.
Moving the light source forward will increase the angle of the light rays, causing Shadow A to become longer and narrower.
Shadow B is cast by another object.
Moving the light source forward will cause Shadow B to stretch out, becoming longer and potentially wider depending on the object's orientation.
Shadow C is cast by the object with pink frosting.
As the light source moves forward, Shadow C will elongate, becoming more stretched out.
Shadow D is the shadow of the largest object, with the cherry on top.
As the light source moves forward, Shadow D will stretch out, becoming longer and possibly wider if the object leans further towards the ground.
All shadows will move further away from their original positions, extending outward due to the increased angle of the light rays.
The shadows will generally get larger because the light rays will spread out more, capturing a broader area on the ground.
Some shadows might also become thinner due to the increased angle, especially if the objects are not perfectly aligned under the light source.
Shadow A will stretch out and become longer and narrower.
Shadow B will stretch out, becoming longer and potentially wider.
Shadow C will stretch out, becoming longer.
Shadow D will stretch out, becoming longer and possibly wider.
Moving the light source forward will cause all shadows to stretch out, but the specific changes will depend on the exact shape and position of each object relative to the new light source location.
